data.title: Print Dialog Appearing intermittently when opening quick-nav: cmd-p

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.12.1
- OS Version: Mac OS 10.12.4

### Add'l Environment Notes:

* VSCode typically running in full screen
* 2 Monitors
* Late 2013 rMBP, 8gb

### Steps to Reproduce:

1. Launch Project
2. Enter Quick-Nav shortcut `Cmd-P` (`âŒ˜-P`)
3. Print Dialog appears over Quick-Nav Menu (**BAD**)
4. Close Print Dialog
5. Enter Quick-Nav shortcut again
6. Print Dialog does not appear
7. Switch to another app and switch Back
8. Process repeats 2-6 (**BAD**)

Seems to occur most reliably after first launching, or after switching back into VSCode from another app. Using `Cmd-Tab` reproduces the problem more reliably than switching apps with the mouse

### Things Checked

1. Relaunched VSCode (no change in behavior)
2. Full Screen/Windowed Mode (no change in behavior)

**Keywords**
Command, Print, Command-P, Quick-Nav

data.title: vscode account to save all settings and extensions
data.body: Feature Request: Would love to be able to create VS Code account to save all settings and extensions to. That way, we could just sign in on any machine where it is installed and all settings would be adjusted and extensions installed.

data.title: editor.renderLineHighlight: "line" - doesn't work anymore
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.12.1
- OS Version: Windows 10

Option editor.renderLineHighlight: "line" is not working anymore. The current line is no longer highlighted with a border, it is only highlighted with a background - it's like having the "all" option enabled.

data.title: Add support for import()
data.body:
VSCode: 1.12.1

I'm using Webpack 2 `import()` to dynamically load a scss file like this:
```javascript
import("./styles/main.scss");
```

VSCode throws the following error:

> severity: 'Error'
> message: 'Declaration or statement expected.'
> at: '1,1'
> source: 'js'

Is there any way to suppress this error?

data.title: Suggestion: Support per-file-extension configuration of "files.trimTrailingWhitespace"
data.body: Generally I set `"files.trimTrailingWhitespace"` to `true` as a best practice, however some file formats (such as markdown) consider trailing whitespace to be significant.

data.title: UX: unnecessary modal dialog before reverting a hunk
data.body:
VSCode 1.12:

When invoking _Git: Revert Selected Ranges_, I get this modal dialog:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/101152/25821224/8b4dffc6-3434-11e7-88c0-16cbf4a3c224.png)

As I can always just Ctrl+Z if I'm not happy with the changes, I think this dialog is unnecessary.

data.title: Vs Code fails to get the encoding of the file
data.body:
Look at the following issue https://github.com/pre-commit/pre-commit/issues/519

VS Code has issue recognising the encoding of pre-commit file

- VSCode Version: 1.12
- OS Version: OSX 10.10

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Configure pre-commit tool for your repo
2. Try committing the a file from gui. Notice the following error

> An unexpected error has occurred: LookupError: unknown encoding: 
> Check the log at ~/.pre-commit/pre-commit.log

data.title: Automate identifying, labeling, and closing stale issues
data.body:
Outlining some of our ideas:
- Inbox:
  - [x] Identify area (was: bugs / feature requests / ...)
  - [x] Label issues filed for an insiders build as `insiders`.
  - [x] Label issues filed for a recently released stable build as `new release`.
  - [ ] Search for duplicate issues.
  - [ ] On bugs: Ask author to add VSCode and OS versions when not provided, also label as `needs more info`.
  - [ ] Check description is not empty, label as `needs more info`.
- Maintenance:
  - [x] Close `needs more info` issues when the last comment is from our team when stale for 7 days.
  - [ ] Close feature requests stale for 30 days with either no assignee or no milestone and with less than 20 up-votes
    - Here 'stale' should include no addition of votes, so the voting has largely finished.
    - We need to check the existing issues to assess if 30 days and 20 up-votes are good values.
  - [ ] Close bugs stale for 60 days with either no milestone or on the backlog

/cc @kieferrm

data.title: Feature: Add Folder to project
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.12.1
- OS Version: 16.04 LTS

I'd really like a Add Folder to Project feature just like in Atom, you can open multiple folders in the same window, and working from them. In my version of VSCode, when i use the open folder option, it opens a new instance of VSCode. Please this would a nice feature to add.

data.title: Theming: Bad tree selection overlay when sidebar border is active
data.body:
Today when you specify a theme customization such as the following:

The result is not very pleasant:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/900690/25811312/2a60bdfa-3413-11e7-99aa-98c876be59dc.png)

Bottom line is that our borders are `box-sizing: border-box` and as such the borders are going into the element. This means that any div inside the element that has a 100% width will draw over the border.

data.title: IntelliSense window got a lot more narrow with docs to the side
data.body:
This is quite a bad user experience imho because I am typically not paying too much attention to the docs but rather the suggestion in IntelliSense. With todays build I am seeing quite a bit of horizontal space taken away to the documentation:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/900690/25810951/ed8b2cea-3411-11e7-8539-69a92e2feb16.png)

Maybe make this configurable at least? Or provide an explicit gesture to bring up docs when needed?

/cc @joaomoreno

data.title: Add a way to organize files opened by shell which neither spawns new windows all the time nor pollutes project windows
data.body:
I have Windows 10, and when I open a file in code from the shell, either from command line or by double clicking a file or by opening a file from WinSCP where I have configured VSCode as editor, it opens in a seemingly random existing window where I usually have other things open (unless no window is open).

I assume it is actually not a random window but the last active window or something like that, but nevertheless it is annoying and causes chaos (files being opened in projects they don't belong to, files being opened multiple times inside different projects' windows, ...), and I can't even manually fix it because tabs can't be moved between Windows.

~~I think it would be great to allow a configuration like this:~~ _I have been enlightened that two of these options already exist as the option `window.openFilesInNewWindow`. Nevertheless I seek an option which neither pollutes existing windows which belong to a project nor opens new windows all the time._

* ~~Open in last active window (I guess this is the current behavior)~~
* ~~Always open in new window~~
* Open in a dedicated window for shell-opened files (open such a window if it doesn't exist yet)

Maybe even some setting per-window where we can set a specific window as target for all the next file-opening operations from the shell, if we want to...

It could already be mitigating most of the pain if VSCode would just never consider windows which have a project opened in them as targets for shell-opened files, but instead use other non-project windows or create one.

EDIT: Based on the fact that half of this already exists, as I now know, I would love to have a mode which reads "Files will open in the window with the files' folder open or ~~the last active window~~ a dedicated window for externally opened files. If such a window doesn't yet exist, it will be created." I understand that it may be not so straight-forward to do this because I ask for a special property of such a window which would need to be marked and I see that the transition to a normal window would be very short because users should of course be able to open other files in this window as well, so I'm not 100% sure yet what could be a good way to solve this - maybe a combination with my idea of a per-window exclusive flag, i.e. "Files will open in the window with the files' folder open or _the window marked as target for externally open files_. If no such window exists, it will be created." and a way to move this flag.

Maybe I think too complicated, though, but the bottom line of my request is that files should never be opened in a window which has a folder open which the file is not in. And I think that in any event "Last active" is not such a good choice because with several windows open one usually doesn't even remember which window happened to be last in focus when opening a file at another place...

data.title: ctrl + 1 does not switch to first editor tab

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.12.1
- OS Version: macOS Sierra version 10.12.2

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open several tabs/editors. Switch around with `ctrl` + tab index
2. All indices work except for `ctrl` + 1 which brings me to my desktop 1 rather than first tab.
